author: TONY WALL
title: How a Tauranga woman fought back through the justice system
text:
How a Tauranga woman fought back through the justice system TONY WALL Last updated 17:11, February 23 2017 ROSS BROWN/VISION MEDIA 
Tamsin Trainor was attacked by Neihana Rangitonga about seven years ago. 
A Tauranga woman who was told there was no way to prosecute a man who attacked her has won a landmark private prosecution. 
ï»¿ Almost seven years after she was attacked in a park by Neihana Rangitonga, Tamsin Trainor has finally received justice thanks to her perserverance and the support of a legal team working pro bono. 
The case had bounced between the district, high and appeal courts after a string of appeals by Rangitonga - but on Thursday he pleaded guilty in the Tauranga District Court to a charge of injuring with intent. 
Rangitonga is serving a jail sentence for another attack. 
READ MORE: Young mum's fight for justice 
"It's really good," said Trainor, who is about to go into labour with her fifth child. 
"He got to sit in jail on legal aid, defending and lying and trying to snake his way out of it - he's abusing legal aid in my opinion if he does that and then pleads guilty. 
"Meanwhile, I was fortunate enough to be able to rely on the goodwill of people that truly stand for justice - and justice prevailed." 
In 2010, the 31-year-old was attacked by Rangitonga after she accepted his offer to take drugs in a park, then changed her mind and tried to leave. 
The Crown originally charged him with rape and wounding with intent Ad Feedback 
He had allegedly punched her in the head and held her throat until she passed out, the Crown later dropped the wounding charge so the jury could focus on the rape. He was acquitted on the rape charge. 
Rangitonga went on to abduct an intoxicated woman for sex from a Mt Maunganui Burger King drive-thru and was jailed for four years in 2014. 
The decision to drop the original wounding charge outraged some police. In an internal memo, officer in charge Detective Sergeant Darryl Brazier wrote: "I believe it was clearly the wrong decision by the Crown ... This has resulted in a violent [offender] walking free from the court." 
For Trainor, the outcome was devastating. She drank heavily and had frequent brushes with the law, finally being jailed for six months in 2011 for an assault on her mother. 
After her release she got her life back on track, focused on her four children, and began investigating ways of getting justice. 
She wrote to the solicitor-general, asking that a new wounding charge be laid against Rangitonga. 
Deputy solicitor-general Brendan Horsley wrote back saying although technically possible, "it would be entirely inappropriate to relay a charge that the prosecutor had told Mr Rangitonga would not be proceeded with". 
He said although Rangitonga had admitted in court to losing his temper, slamming Trainor against a tree and "smacking you over", a fresh prosecution would have little chance of being successful as Rangitonga could use a number of legal avenues to have the charge dismissed. 
Trainor made contact with Shannon Parker, president of the New Zealand Police Conduct Association, which helps people with complaints against police. 
The two began working on a private prosecution. 
"I'm at a loss to understand why the Crown withdrew the charge in the first place when there was so much evidence. I cannot understand why the police didn't relay the charge after the offender made an admission in 2012," Parker said. 
In 2014, a judge ruled that a charge of injuring with intent could be accepted by the court and a summons was issued to Rangitonga. 
Trainor, who had automatic name suppression lifted so she could talk publicly about the case, said she could hardly believe it. 
"I've felt extremely saddened by it over the years and those feelings just would not leave me alone. It was never over for me. 
"Maybe the worst thing that's happened to me in my life has led to one of the best things, because this is really empowering." 
She paid tribute to Parker and the police officers who supported her, especially Brazier, as well as the lawyers who worked on the case, Paul Davison, QC, Marc Corlett QC and Craig Tuck. 
Rangitonga has been remanded for sentencing. - Stuff
